origin: Old English eorl, of Germanic origin. The word earl originally denoted a man of noble rank, as opposed to a churl, also specifically a hereditary nobleman next above the rank of thane. It was later an equivalent of jarl and, under Canute and his successors, applied to the governor of divisions of England such as Wessex. In the late Old English period, as the Saxon court came under Norman influence, the word was applied to any nobleman bearing the continental title of count (see count2).

an ancient school of philosophy founded in Athens by Epicurus. The school rejected determinism and advocated hedonism (pleasure as the highest good), but of a restrained kind: mental pleasure was regarded more highly than physical, and the ultimate pleasure was held to be freedom from anxiety and mental pain, especially that arising from needless fear of death and of the gods.

Developed largely by Sir Francis Galton as a method of improving the human race, eugenics was increasingly discredited as unscientific and racially biased during the 20th century, especially after the adoption of its doctrines by the Nazis in order to justify their treatment of Jews, disabled people, and other minority groups.

origin: late 15th century (in the sense ‘perform quickly’): from Latin expedire ‘extricate (originally by freeing the feet), put in order’, from ex- ‘out’ + pes, ped- ‘foot’.

definitions.definition: make (an action or process) happen sooner or be accomplished more quickly.

definitions.definition: of or forming an expedition, especially a military expedition.

origin: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin expeditio(n- ), from expedire ‘extricate’ (see expedite). Early senses included ‘prompt supply of something’ and ‘setting out with aggressive intent’. The notions of ‘speed’ and ‘purpose’ are retained in current senses. expedition (sense 1) dates from the late 16th century.

definitions.definition: a journey undertaken by a group of people with a particular purpose, especially that of exploration, research, or war.

definitions.definition: promptness or speed in doing something.

definitions.definition: with speed and efficiency.

origin: late 15th century: from expedition + -ous.

origin: late Middle English: from Latin expellere, from ex- ‘out’ + pellere ‘to drive’.

definitions.definition: of relatively little significance, and therefore able to be abandoned or destroyed.

origin: mid 18th century: from expend, suggested by obsolete expenditor  ‘officer in charge of expenditure’, from medieval Latin, from expenditus, irregular past participle of Latin expendere (see expend).

origin: late Middle English: from Latin expendere, from ex- ‘out’ + pendere ‘weigh, pay’. Compare with spend.

origin: late Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French, alteration of Old French espense, from late Latin expensa (pecunia) ‘(money) spent’, from Latin expendere ‘pay out’ (see expend).

origin: late Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French, alteration of Old French espense, from late Latin expensa (pecunia) ‘(money) spent’, from Latin expendere ‘pay out’ (see expend).

origin: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin experientia, from experiri ‘try’. Compare with experiment and expert.

origin: late Middle English (as an adjective): from late Latin expletivus, from explere ‘fill out’, from ex- ‘out’ + plere ‘fill’. The noun sense ‘word used merely to fill out a sentence’ (early 17th century) was applied specifically to a swear word in the early 19th century.

definitions.definition: an oath or swear word.

definitions.definition: burst or shatter violently and noisily as a result of rapid combustion, excessive internal pressure, or other process.

definitions.definition: increase suddenly in size, number, or extent.

definitions.definition: show (a belief or theory) to be false or unfounded.

origin: Middle English: from Old French esploit (noun), based on Latin explicare ‘unfold’ (see explicate). Verb senses (mid 19th century) are from modern French exploiter .

definitions.definition: a translucent visor used to protect the eyes from strong light.
definitions.example: the stereotype of the forger as the chap with the green eyeshade and specs

definitions.definition: a coloured cosmetic applied to the eyelids or to the skin around the eyes to accentuate them.
the distance for which one can see.
definitions.example: he is within eyeshot

definitions.definition: a person's ability to see.
definitions.example: poor eyesight ended his plans for a naval career

definitions.definition: a military command to turn the head to the left.
definitions.example: they still march in perfect step, and at the command ‘eyes left’, snapped towards the podium for the salute

definitions.definition: the cavity in the skull which encloses an eyeball with its surrounding muscles.
a thing that is very ugly, especially a building.
definitions.example: the office crumbled into an eyesore

definitions.definition: used to emphasize the extreme degree of someone's eager curiosity.
definitions.example: when I read about his arrest my eyes popped out on stalks

definitions.definition: as fast or as hard as possible.
definitions.example: the whole team went eyes out from the start

definitions.definition: a splice made by turning the end of a rope back on itself and interlacing the strands, thereby forming a loop.
a light-sensitive pigmented spot on the bodies of invertebrates such as flatworms, starfishes, and microscopic crustaceans, and also in some unicellular organisms.
a rounded eye-like marking on an animal, especially on the wing of a butterfly or moth.
a fungal disease of cereals and other cultivated grasses, characterized by yellowish oval spots on the leaves and stems.
a military command to turn the head to the right.
definitions.example: as the officers approached the monarch the order of ‘eyes right’ was shouted out

definitions.definition: a movable stalk that bears an eye near its tip, especially in crabs, shrimps, and related crustaceans, and in some molluscs.
fatigue of the eyes, such as that caused by reading or looking at a computer screen for too long.
definitions.example: avoid eye strain and have your sight checked regularly

definitions.definition: a stripe on a bird's head which encloses or appears to run through the eye.

origin: early 20th century (in the form Iti ): abbreviation of 19th-century Eyetalian, representing a humorous pronunciation of Italian .

definitions.definition: an Italian person.
a canine tooth, especially one in the upper jaw.

the recording and study of the movements of the eyes in following a moving object, lines of printed text, or other visual stimulus, used as a diagnostic procedure or a means of evaluating and improving the visual presentation of information.
definitions.example: the company uses webcam-based eye tracking to monitor how consumers absorb content and advertising

definitions.definition: cleansing lotion for a person's eye.
insincere talk; nonsense.
definitions.example: all that stuff about blood being thicker than water was a lot of eyewash

definitions.definition: causing the eyes to water.
definitions.example: eye-watering Scotch bonnet chillies

definitions.definition: (especially of a figure or amount) extremely high or large.
definitions.example: an eye-watering 22% rise in business rates

definitions.definition: water secreted by the eyes; tears.
things worn on the eyes, such as spectacles and contact lenses.
a person who has seen something happen and can give a first-hand description of it.
definitions.example: eyewitness accounts of the London blitz

definitions.definition: either of two parasitic nematode worms which affect the eyes of mammals.

origin: early 17th century: from Spanish, from Tupi eirara, irara .

definitions.definition: a reddish-brown form of the jaguarundi (cat).

origin: Middle English: from Old French eire, from Latin iter ‘journey’.

definitions.definition: a circuit court held in medieval England by a judge (a justice in eyre ) who rode from county to county.
definitions.example: in 1221 six justices went on eyre (or circuit) in the western counties

origin: late 15th century: from medieval Latin aeria, aerea, eyria, probably from Old French aire, from Latin area ‘level piece of ground’, in late Latin‘nest of a bird of prey’.

definitions.definition: a large nest of an eagle or other bird of prey, built high in a tree or on a cliff.

origin: Icelandic, from Old Norse, literally ‘ounce (of silver etc.), money’, probably from Latin aureus ‘golden, a golden coin’.

definitions.definition: a monetary unit of Iceland, equal to one hundredth of a krona.
Ezekiel (in biblical references).
a magazine only published in electronic form on a computer network.
